coverage: Comprehensive Joel: elders, priests, full assembly; twin trumpet blasts; four locust waves & ‘northern army’; ecology-economy-cult shutdown; Day of YHWH portents; repentance liturgies and God’s restorative answer (grain/wine/oil, rains, restored years); Spirit outpouring and universal call; nations on trial (Tyre, Sidon, Philistia, Javan, Egypt, Edom) in the Valley of Jehoshaphat/Decision; Zion theology (temple fountain, mountains dripping new wine, indwelling presence); literary notes and Acts 2 reception.
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) with alias support; deterministic for new entries; reuses shared entities where present.

entries.name: Superscription: Joel son of Pethuel
entries.blurb: Names the prophet and locates the book within Judah’s prophetic stream; precise reign-date is unstated.

entries.name: Dating (debated)
entries.blurb: Scholars place Joel anywhere from 9th–5th century BCE. Internal cues (no king named; temple central; mention of Greeks) often suggest a post‑exilic or later monarchic context. We retain canonical theology while noting the debate.

entries.name: Audience: Judah and Jerusalem
entries.blurb: Summons focus on Zion and the temple community; the nations are addressed as adversaries called to judgment.

entries.name: Elders (gray‑beards)
entries.blurb: First addressed to remember and testify; they convene fasts and anchor communal memory.

entries.name: Priests, ministers of YHWH
entries.blurb: Weeping between porch and altar, priests model repentance and intercede for the people’s reproach to be lifted.

entries.name: People: consecrated assembly (qahal)
entries.blurb: From infants to elders, bridegroom to bride—whole community gathered for emergency worship.

entries.name: Bridegroom & bride withheld from chamber
entries.blurb: Even joys of marriage pause for corporate repentance—covenant takes precedence over celebration.

entries.name: Infants and nursing babies
entries.blurb: Extremes of age included so the whole body bears the fast—dependence highlights urgency.

entries.name: Farmers & vinedressers
entries.blurb: Economic backbone hit first by devastation—lament trained through agrarian loss.

entries.name: Drunkards & drinkers of wine
entries.blurb: Called to awaken first; indulgence interrupted by the cutting off of new wine.

entries.name: Blow the trumpet in Zion (alarm)
entries.blurb: Sirens of holiness: the shofar warns of the Day of YHWH—a sacred emergency broadcast.

entries.name: Blow the trumpet in Zion (fast)
entries.blurb: Second blast convenes a holy fast and solemn assembly; sound organizes repentance.

entries.name: Fast: consecrate a fast, call a sacred assembly
entries.blurb: Fasting becomes national therapy—lean bodies saying what words cannot.

entries.name: Sackcloth (priests & people)
entries.blurb: Scratchy sign of grief; external symbol to train internal contrition.

entries.name: Between porch and altar (intercession locus)
entries.blurb: Spatial theology: priests stand in the hinge between God and people, pleading for mercy and reputation of the Name.

entries.name: Gnawing locust (gazam)
entries.blurb: First wave in the consumption cycle—chews through initial growth.

entries.name: Swarming locust (arbeh)
entries.blurb: Cloud of eaters saturating the sky; the most common biblical locust term.

entries.name: Creeping/young locust (yeleq)
entries.blurb: Larval hoppers stripping what remains at ground level.

entries.name: Destroying locust (ḥasil)
entries.blurb: Final, finishing wave—nothing green remains.

entries.name: Locusts as YHWH’s army
entries.blurb: Similes of cavalry, chariots, and disciplined ranks reframe nature as a divine instrument of holy war.

entries.name: Northern army (driven to seas)
entries.blurb: Whether locusts or foreign troops, the threat from the north is expelled—stench left as sign of victory.
entries.note: Interpretations differ on whether this denotes insects or invaders.

entries.name: Grain offering and drink offering cut off
entries.blurb: Temple liturgy stalls when fields fail—worship tied to economy and ecology.

entries.name: New wine cut off
entries.blurb: Pleasure pipeline closes; convivial culture sobers to reality.

entries.name: Oil languishes
entries.blurb: Olive-based economy collapses; light and anointing thin out.

entries.name: Fields wasted; ground mourns
entries.blurb: Creation personified as grieving participant in covenant drama.

entries.name: Beasts groan; herds perplexed
entries.blurb: Animal suffering underscores human sin’s collateral damage.

entries.name: Pastures consumed by fire
entries.blurb: Heat and drought turn fields into tinder—judgment through weather and flame.

entries.name: Day of YHWH (near and great)
entries.blurb: Event and horizon: a crisis that unmasks idols and crowns God’s kingship over all nations.

entries.name: Eden before them, desert behind them
entries.blurb: Reversal of creation—locust march leaves de‑creation in its wake.

entries.name: Like horses… like chariots
entries.blurb: Sound and speed metaphors heighten dread; natural disaster reads like invasion.

entries.name: Earthquakes, heavens tremble
entries.blurb: Cosmos participates in judgment—seismic sympathy.

entries.name: Sun turned to darkness, moon to blood
entries.blurb: Apocalyptic optics announce the great and terrible day.

entries.name: Stars withdraw their shining
entries.blurb: Lights dim at the approach of the Divine Warrior.

entries.name: YHWH roars from Zion
entries.blurb: The Divine Lion’s voice steadies Jerusalem and shakes the nations.

entries.name: Return to me with all your heart
entries.blurb: Tear hearts, not garments—appeal to God’s name as gracious and compassionate.

entries.name: Between porch and altar prayer
entries.blurb: ‘Spare your people… make not your heritage a reproach’—intercession centers God’s reputation among nations.

entries.name: Divine jealousy and pity
entries.blurb: God is stirred to zeal for his land and compassion for his people—covenant mercy activated.

entries.name: Restoration of grain, wine, oil
entries.blurb: Liturgy restocked—grace measured in sacks and skins.

entries.name: Removal of northern threat
entries.blurb: Enemy expelled—shame reversed before watching nations.

entries.name: Rains: early and latter
entries.blurb: Covenant weather returns; agricultural rhythms healed.

entries.name: Threshing floors full; vats overflow
entries.blurb: Abundance images replace famine—signs of covenant renewal.

entries.name: I will restore the years the locust has eaten
entries.blurb: Time itself redeemed; losses become sites of testimony.

entries.name: My people shall never again be put to shame
entries.blurb: Reputation repaired; knowledge of God relocates identity.

entries.name: Afterward: I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh
entries.blurb: Pentecostal horizon: democratized prophecy (sons, daughters, old, young, servants) as sign of the age to come.

entries.name: Everyone who calls on the name of YHWH shall be saved
entries.blurb: Open invitation anchored in Zion; later echoed in apostolic preaching.

entries.name: Remnant on Mount Zion
entries.blurb: In Jerusalem there will be survivors whom the LORD calls—election reframed as mission.

entries.name: Valley of Jehoshaphat (YHWH judges)
entries.blurb: Courtroom-battlefield where God gathers nations to answer for crimes against Judah.

entries.name: Valley of Decision
entries.blurb: Human indecision meets divine decision—finality thundered over multitudes.

entries.name: Tyre and Sidon
entries.blurb: Phoenician traders indicted for plunder and slave-trading of Judeans.

entries.name: Philistia (all the districts)
entries.blurb: Coastal enemies complicit in trafficking captives for profit.

entries.name: Javan (Greeks/Ionians)
entries.blurb: Distant buyers of Judean slaves—global market implicated in covenant crimes.

entries.name: Egypt (desolation declared)
entries.blurb: Neighbor empire judged for violence against Judah.

entries.name: Edom (desolate wilderness)
entries.blurb: Kinsfolk-turned-enemy condemned for bloodguilt.

entries.name: Sanctify war: ‘Beat your plowshares into swords’
entries.blurb: Ironic reversal of Isaiah 2/Micah 4—God summons nations to their own undoing.

entries.name: Let the weak say, ‘I am a warrior’
entries.blurb: Bitter parody of empowerment—mustering for judgment, not justice.

entries.name: Sickle and winepress of wrath
entries.blurb: Harvest metaphors for judgment ripeness—grapes of wrath trodden.

entries.name: Zion/Jerusalem as refuge
entries.blurb: Holy hill becomes sanctuary; knowing the LORD sets boundaries against profanation.

entries.name: Fountain from the house of YHWH
entries.blurb: Temple-spring irrigates the Valley of Shittim—Edenic waters return to heal land.

entries.name: Mountains drip new wine; hills flow with milk
entries.blurb: Hyperbolic agrarian joy—creation re‑enchanted under divine reign.

entries.name: Valley of Shittim (Acacias) watered
entries.blurb: Dry places transformed by temple river—judgment land remade into garden.

entries.name: Foreigners shall never again pass through her
entries.blurb: Sanctity protected—no trampling of holy space by hostile powers.

entries.name: YHWH dwells in Zion
entries.blurb: Covenant climax: divine presence restores belonging and holiness.

entries.name: Priestly diction & temple centrality
entries.blurb: Joel’s language and remedies are cultically inflected—fasts, offerings, priests, and altar define the cure.

entries.name: Intertexts: Amos, Isaiah, Obadiah
entries.blurb: Joel echoes and is echoed—Day of YHWH, Zion refuge, and Edom/Egypt judgments cycle through the Twelve.

entries.name: Acts 2 reception of Joel 2
entries.blurb: Peter reads Pentecost as the ‘afterward’—outpoured Spirit signals the last days.

entries.name: Isaiah–Micah plowshares reversal
entries.blurb: Joel’s muster to war flips Zion’s peace oracle—irony intensifies judgment theme.

entries.name: Theology of reversal: from famine to feast
entries.blurb: Loss → lament → liturgy → life restored: a canonical pattern of death and resurrection.

entries.name: Gnats of ash and dust (implied in drought)
entries.blurb: Parched creation hints at plague ecology—Joel’s silence roars in images.

entries.name: Windows of the temple (priests’ vantage)
entries.blurb: Between porch and altar imagines a clerical threshold where mercy is pled.

entries.name: Naming shame vs. name of YHWH
entries.blurb: Public disgrace replaced by public invocation—identity rebuilt by the Name.

entries.name: ‘Who can endure it?’ rhetorical question
entries.blurb: Apocalyptic humility—no presumption survives the Day, only repentance.

entries.name: Multitudes, multitudes…
entries.blurb: Poetic doubling amplifies dread and decisiveness.
